content.question:
The enzyme trypsin aids in protein digestion in the small intestine. The relative activity of trypsin at different <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> values is shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1. Effect of <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the activity of trypsin

Which of the following statements best explains the activity levels of trypsin shown in Figure 1 ?

choices.label: The small intestine releases inhibitor molecules that block the activity of trypsin unless it is at its optimum <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The number of effective collisions between trypsin and its substrate increase at higher <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> values.

As <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> values increase, the substrate concentration decreases, leading to an eventual decline in the rate of the trypsin-catalyzed reaction.
At extremely low <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> values, trypsin is denatured and cannot function efficiently.

content.answer: At extremely low <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> values, trypsin is denatured and cannot function efficiently.

skill.text: 2.B: Explain relationships between characteristics of biological models in both theoretical and applied contexts.
